author: mariusvanderwijden
content:
Yes, there have been several community calls with companies in the ecosystem regarding eip1559, I'm not sure if GasStation and GasNow attended.
Maybe <@!552133098075193354> can fill in the blanks
Regarding the mempool, yes transactions with insufficient basefee will eventually be dropped (just as outpriced transactions right now), but (at least geth's) txpool will keep underpriced transactions in as long as possible, for a writeup of the txpool changes see: https://gist.github.com/zsfelfoldi/9607ad248707a925b701f49787904fd6

content: I still do not understand why after 1559  miners tip is so predictable that services like gas station will be not necessary anymore.

author: sky.cactus
content: These services can continue to work as they do today, without any changes to them.  They will continue to serve users who are submitting legacy transactions.

author: .funnyking
content: I can't wait to see 1559 in action to understand

author: sky.cactus
content: Initially, miners will likely set a static minimum premium that is stable for the run of the miner.

author: sky.cactus
content: In theory, some miners may *choose* to write a "smarter" algorithm that adjusts based on a block's value (where high extractable value blocks are worth more) in which case the minimum priority fee may fluctuate from block to block.

author: sky.cactus
content: Even in the case where miners develop optimizing algorithms, we don't *expect* for the minimum miner premium (based on historic data and assumption of rational miners) to fluctuate by more than 1-5 nanoeth / gas.

author: sky.cactus
content: In all cases, we suspect there will be an equilibrium reached pretty quickly that doesn't change a lot with time (nothing like gas prices of today).

author: .funnyking
content: Ok I definitely miss something in how 1559 works, I thought that miners can use tip to prioritize tx more or less as today, in case of congestion.

author: Deleted User
content: The way I understand it is that in the normal regime (when base fee is not changing due to increase in incoming transactions) the tip that users set doesn’t really change anything (since the base fee makes sure your tx gets included). That’s why it’s expected that most user will default their tip to minimum.

author: Deleted User
content: <@433705373070000138> this talk  https://youtu.be/ndNyx-Oj9Wk  really explains 1559 well, it’s definitely worth the time.

author: sky.cactus
content: Only during times of **changing** congestion.  Specifically, when the demand for blockspace increases by more than 2x between two blocks.

author: sky.cactus
content: The system will automatically adjust to any level of demand for blockspace, but it can only adjust at a maximum speed.  If the change in demand is greater than the adjustment rate, then we will end up with a small number of blocks where the gas premium is used for sorting and exclusion of the lowest.

author: sky.cactus
content: These situations are expected to be rare, and when they happen they are expected to be short lived.  We'll know more on their frequency and duration after launch.
